moves.1. f4: It doesn't crop up very often but when facing Bird's Opening I like to play From's Gambit. I don't play many gambits as I don't like giving away pawns but I particularly like this variation with 4 . . g5 as black seems to have reasonable compensation.
moves.1... e5 2. fxe5 d6 3. exd6 Bxd6 4. Nf3 g: {black has given up a pawn but is threatening to immediately force the Knight from f3}
moves.5. g3 Nc6 6. Bg2 g4 7. Nh4 Nge7 8. b3 Ng: {hoping for Nxg6 hxg6 opening the h file . . .}
moves.9. Bxc6+: {white avoids opening the h file by making g2 available for the Knight but giving up the light squared Bishop seemed risky even if it did weaken Black's pawns.}
moves.9... bxc6 10. Ng2 Be5: {Shredder likes this move, stopping white getting any pressure with Bb2}
moves.11. Nc3 h5: {ignoring what I recommend to juniors about developing pieces quickly when teaching chess but Shredder also played this move so I guess it's okay.}
moves.12. Bb2 h4: Continuing the pawn advance, Shredder also plays this move}
moves.13. e3: {taking on h4 is no better for white after ... Nxh4}
moves.13... hxg3: {regaining not just the gambit pawn but also the h pawn}
moves.14. Qe2 Qe7 15. O-O-O gxh2: {I had slight concerns about my lack of development but there's no way for white to exploit this.}
moves.16. d4 Bd6 17. e4: {threatening to trap my Bishop with e5 but I anticipated this and after my Nf4 expected to exchange on g2 and follow up with Bf4+ and Qg5.}
moves.17... Nf4: {Shredder prefers f6 here but this felt more forcing?}
moves.18. Nxf4: {Shredder likes Qd2 which it gives as slightly better for black.}
moves.18... Bxf4+ 19. Kb1 g3: {my 10th pawn move, whilst a Bishop is still resting on c8 and my King still on e8! I'm often telling juniors to limit pawn moves to 3 in the first 10 and instead develop pieces and castle early! but I felt this was justified and I also advise them that there are often exceptions to the rule.}
moves.20. Qc4: {Attacking c6 but Bd7 is intended anyway so this seems wrong?}
moves.20... Bd7 21. Qf1 Qg5: {defending the Bishop and threatening g2 and Bishop h3}
moves.22. Ne2: {Losing the exchange but white has nothing better.}
moves.22... g2 23. Qxf4 Qxf4 24. Nxf4 gxh1=Q 2: {better late than never and mainly to activate the other Rook.}
moves.26. d5: {forced to enable the white Bishop to get to d4 preventing my d8 Rook moving to g1 via g8 but this allows black to eventually manoeuvre the Bishop to c6}
moves.27... Rh4 28. Ne2 Rg2 29. Nc3 cxd5 30. N: {to prevent Rg1+ (as Rg1 would then be met with Rxh2 and if Ne3 then Rg1)}
moves.32... Kb7 33. Be3 Bc6 34. Nf4 Rxc2+:
{and after Kxc2 and Bxh1, the h pawn is going to Queen so white resigns.} 
0 - 1

Entered the game for the Worcestershire Woodcock Prize and won it for the first time!

Thanks for looking.
